  (function () {
    var noop = function noop() {};
    if ("performance" in window === false) {
      window.performance = {};
    }
    window.performance.mark = performance.mark || noop;
    window.performance.measure = performance.measure || noop;
    if ("now" in window.performance === false) {
      var nowOffset = Date.now();
      if (performance.timing && performance.timing.navigationStart) {
        nowOffset = performance.timing.navigationStart;
      }
      window.performance.now = function now() {
        return Date.now() - nowOffset;
      };
    }
  })();

<title>BiBi-Linux: A New Wiper Dropped By Pro-Hamas Hacktivist Group</title>
  <link rel="canonical" href="https://www.securityjoes.com/post/bibi-linux-a-new-wiper-dropped-by-pro-hamas-hacktivist-group"/>
  <meta property="og:title" content="BiBi-Linux: A New Wiper Dropped By Pro-Hamas Hacktivist Group"/>
  <meta property="og:description" content="Security Joes Incident Response team volunteered to assist Israeli companies during the times of war between the state of Israel and the terrorist organization Hamas. During the forensics investigation, we found what appears to be a new Linux Wiper malware we track as BiBi-Linux Wiper.This malware is an x64 ELF executable, lacking obfuscation or protective measures. It allows attackers to specify target folders and can potentially destroy an entire operating system if run with root permissions. "/>
  <meta property="og:image" content="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/e17082_555899aaa92e4945b305e9c2ee1f65c1~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_992,h_1000,al_c,q_90,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01/e17082_555899aaa92e4945b305e9c2ee1f65c1~mv2.png"/>

  <script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Security Joes","url":"https://www.securityjoes.com/profile/4939792a-8ef0-4c74-b454-6ef01c32511e/profile"},"dateModified":"2023-10-30T16:44:47.428Z","datePublished":"2023-10-30T13:04:56.685Z","headline":"BiBi-Linux: A New Wiper Dropped By Pro-Hamas Hacktivist Group","mainEntityOfPage":{"@id":"https://www.securityjoes.com/post/bibi-linux-a-new-wiper-dropped-by-pro-hamas-hacktivist-group","@type":"itemPage","url":"https://www.securityjoes.com/post/bibi-linux-a-new-wiper-dropped-by-pro-hamas-hacktivist-group"},"description":"Security Joes Incident Response team volunteered to assist Israeli companies during the times of war between the state of Israel and the terrorist organization Hamas. During the forensics investigation, we found what appears to be a new Linux Wiper malware we track as BiBi-Linux Wiper.This malware is an x64 ELF executable, lacking obfuscation or protective measures. It allows attackers to specify target folders and can potentially destroy an entire operating system if run with root permissions. During the forensics investigation, we found what appears to be a new Linux Wiper malware we track as BiBi-Linux Wiper.This malware is an x64 ELF executable, lacking obfuscation or protective measures. It allows attackers to specify target folders and can potentially destroy an entire operating system if run with root permissions. "/>

    var ssrInfo = {"cacheExclusionReason":"","renderBodyTime":1501,"renderTimeStamp":1729698996016}

<script id="wix-first-paint">
    if (window.ResizeObserver &&
        (!window.PerformanceObserver || !PerformanceObserver.supportedEntryTypes || PerformanceObserver.supportedEntryTypes.indexOf('paint') === -1)) {
        new ResizeObserver(function (entries, observer) {
            entries.some(function (entry) {
                var contentRect = entry.contentRect;
                if (contentRect.width > 0 && contentRect.height > 0) {
                    requestAnimationFrame(function (now) {
                        window.wixFirstPaint = now;
                        dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent('wixFirstPaint'));
                    });
                    observer.disconnect();
                    return true;
                }
            });
        }).observe(document.body);
    }
</script>

id="viewer-cvpa"><div class="SErax c8QuI" style="width:min(100%, 100%)"><figure role="button" data-hook="imageViewer" tabindex="0" class="Eswhf" aria-haspopup="true"><div style="--dim-height:1053;--dim-width:1045" id="cvpa" class="_2ynrX bqdPo z-4Pg"><wow-image id="e17082_555899aaa92e4945b305e9c2ee1f65c1~mv2.png" class="undefined O4AJH" data-image-info="{&quot;containerId&quot;:&quot;cvpa&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;,&quot;isLQIP&quot;:true,&quot;isSEOBot&quot;:false,&quot;lqipTransition&quot;:&quot;blur&quot;,&quot;imageData&quot;:{&quot;width&quot;:1045,&quot;height&quot;:1053,&quot;uri&quot;:&quot;e17082_555899aaa92e4945b305e9c2ee1f65c1~mv2.png&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;}}" data-bg-effect-name="" data-has-ssr-src="true" data-animate-blur=""><img src="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/e17082_555899aaa92e4945b305e9c2ee1f65c1~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_49,h_49,al_c,q_85,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01,blur_2,enc_auto/e17082_555899aaa92e4945b305e9c2ee1f65c1~mv2.png" class="VtuvT" role="button" tabindex="0"><svg viewBox="0 0 19 19" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="leGkP"><path d="M15.071 8.371V4.585l-4.355 4.356a.2.2 0 0 1-.283 0l-.374-.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0-.283l4.356-4.355h-3.786a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2V3.2c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2H16v5.371a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2h-.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2zm-6.5 6.9v.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2H3v-5.371c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2h.529c.11 0 type="image" data-hook="rcv-block2"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-9f1uu"><span class="AT4Tn"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block3"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-8evlg"><span class="AT4Tn"><span>Security Joes Incident Response team volunteered to assist Israeli companies during the times of war between the state of Israel and the terrorist organization Hamas. During the forensics investigation, we found what appears to be a new Linux Wiper malware we track as </span><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>BiBi-Linux Wiper.</span></strong></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block4"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-1igle"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block5"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-fmnbm"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>This malware is an x64 ELF executable, lacking obfuscation or protective measures. It allows attackers to specify target folders and can potentially destroy an entire operating system if run with root permissions. During execution, it produces extensive output, which can be mitigated using the &quot;nohup&quot; command. It also leverages multiple threads and a queue to corrupt files concurrently, enhancing its speed and reach. Its actions include overwriting files, renaming them with a random string containing &quot;BiBi,&quot; and excluding certain file types from corruption.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block6"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-aarr0"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block7"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" style="padding-top:0px;padding-bottom:0px;line-height:1.5" dir="auto" id="viewer-e4v3v"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><u style="text-decoration:underline"><span>The article in a nutshell:</span></u></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block8"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><pre class="Rreaj _4EUF1 Pohl9" dir="auto" id="viewer-2ir52"><span class="Pohl9"><span>1. Security Joes Incident Response team voluntarily conducted a forensic investigation within victim networks Israeli companies </span><span>
</span><span>2. Hamas affiliated hacktivist group broke into Israeli companies and deployed a new cyberweapon to destroy their infrastructure</span><span>
</span><span>3. Notably, they decided to hardcode the name of Israeli PM in the malware name and in every destroyed file&#x27;s extension</span><span>
</span><span>4. The attack had no ransom note or C2 servers which increased our confidence that the malware tracked as BiBi-Linux is indeed a Wiper aimed for data destruction </span></span></pre></div><div type="code_block" data-hook="rcv-block9"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-2368q"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>Security Joes is a multi-layered incident response company strategically located in nine different time-zones worldwide, providing a follow-the-sun MDR &amp; IR coverage to respond to any incident remotely. </span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block10"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-675te"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block11"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-3ekjd"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>Contact us at </span><a target="_blank" href="mailto:response@securityjoes.com" rel="noopener" class="hEuCV uw4qb" data-hook="WebLink"><u style="text-decoration:underline"><span>response@securityjoes.com</span></u></a><span> for more information about our services and technologies and get additional recommendations to protect yourself against this kind of attack vector.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block12"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><h2 class="cqXpV XMpE9 WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-bkt6v"><span class="uZXi0"><br role="presentation"/></span></h2></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block13"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><h2 class="cqXpV XMpE9 WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-64c7q"><span class="uZXi0"><span>Warzone Cyberweapon</span></span></h2></div><div type="heading" data-hook="rcv-block14"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-4ib7l"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>During these times of conflict between Israel &amp; Hamas, our team voluntarily decided to respond to incidents affecting Israeli companies. In the course of our investigations, we encountered a highly specific malware sample that is currently targeting companies across the nation. Unlike the typical global distribution of malware, where financial gain is the common motivation, our analysis of these attacks revealed a different motive. In this case, they are not driven by monetary objectives but are deeply rooted in the political ideologies associated with the ongoing war. This leads us to believe that the specific artifacts discovered may have been created by a group of hackers affiliated with Hamas, with the intent to sow chaos amidst the backdrop of the war.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block15"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-1jeru"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block16"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-afqd9"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>This new threat does not establish communication with remote Command &amp; Control (C2) servers for data exfiltration, employ reversible encryption algorithms, or leave ransom notes as a means to coerce victims into making payments. Instead, it conducts file corruption by overwriting files with useless data, damaging both the data and the operating system. This category of destructive software is commonly referred to as a &quot;Wiper&quot; and is not a recent phenomenon.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block17"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-2efn0"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block18"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-faut0"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>Reports of this type of malware have been documented targeting devices in previous years, affecting both </span><a target="_blank" href="https://www.vectra.ai/blog/an-analysis-of-the-shamoon-2-malware-attack" rel="noopener" class="hEuCV uw4qb" data-hook="WebLink"><u style="text-decoration:underline"><span>Windows</span></u></a><span> and </span><a target="_blank" href="https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/acidrain-a-modem-wiper-rains-down-on-europe/" rel="noopener" class="hEuCV uw4qb" data-hook="WebLink"><u style="text-decoration:underline"><span>Linux</span></u></a><span> systems. Historically, such threats are typically associated with complex political situations worldwide, with one notable example being the recent conflict between Ukraine and Russia.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block19"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-9qaeg"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block20"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-f3a3m"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>What particularly caught our attention was the fact that the analyzed binary had never been documented before. As of the writing of this report, it has only received two detections on VirusTotal. This indicates that the malware is relatively new and not widely distributed yet, see Figure 1.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block21"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="tqAje" id="viewer-1if8r"><div class="SErax c8QuI" style="width:min(100%, 100%)"><figure role="button" data-hook="imageViewer" tabindex="0" class="Eswhf" aria-haspopup="true"><div style="--dim-height:499;--dim-width:1355" id="1if8r" class="_2ynrX bqdPo z-4Pg"><wow-image id="d03b6f_395a5bd66f6d4431a35b3aa07eeac71c~mv2.png" class="undefined O4AJH" data-image-info="{&quot;containerId&quot;:&quot;1if8r&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;,&quot;isLQIP&quot;:true,&quot;isSEOBot&quot;:false,&quot;lqipTransition&quot;:&quot;blur&quot;,&quot;imageData&quot;:{&quot;width&quot;:1355,&quot;height&quot;:499,&quot;uri&quot;:&quot;d03b6f_395a5bd66f6d4431a35b3aa07eeac71c~mv2.png&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;}}" data-bg-effect-name="" data-has-ssr-src="true" data-animate-blur=""><img src="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/d03b6f_395a5bd66f6d4431a35b3aa07eeac71c~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_49,h_18,al_c,q_85,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01,blur_2,enc_auto/d03b6f_395a5bd66f6d4431a35b3aa07eeac71c~mv2.png" class="VtuvT" role="button" tabindex="0"><svg viewBox="0 0 19 19" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="leGkP"><path d="M15.071 8.371V4.585l-4.355 4.356a.2.2 0 0 1-.283 0l-.374-.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0-.283l4.356-4.355h-3.786a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2V3.2c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2H16v5.371a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2h-.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2zm-6.5 6.9v.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2H3v-5.371c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2h.529c.11 0 .2.09.2.2v3.786l4.355-4.356a.2.2 0 0 1 .283 0l.374.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0 .283L4.585 15.07h3.786c.11 0 .2.09.2.2z" fill="#000" fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg></div><figcaption dir="auto" class="ki9MR">Figure 1. VirusTotal report of the malicious file discovered during an IR investigation attended by Security Joes.</figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div type="image" data-hook="rcv-block22"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-eogud"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>The malicious file discovered on each of the compromised machines was named </span><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>bibi-linux.out</span></strong><span>. While the string &quot;bibi&quot; (in the filename), may appear random, it holds significant meaning when mixed with topics such as politics in the Middle East, as it is a common nickname used for the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block23"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-mqat"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block24"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-b0tmf"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>The relevance of this particular string became even more apparent when we delved into the inner workings of the malware. Within its structure, we identified this string hardcoded, and it was also employed during the execution of the malware to generate file extensions that identifies the corrupted files.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block25"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="tqAje" id="viewer-efmvo"><div class="SErax c8QuI" style="width:min(100%, 100%)"><figure role="button" data-hook="imageViewer" tabindex="0" class="Eswhf" aria-haspopup="true"><div style="--dim-height:711;--dim-width:730" id="efmvo" class="_2ynrX bqdPo z-4Pg"><wow-image id="e17082_e2b21efb75a74358a12ec8e6d5288d3e~mv2.png" class="undefined O4AJH" data-image-info="{&quot;containerId&quot;:&quot;efmvo&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;,&quot;isLQIP&quot;:true,&quot;isSEOBot&quot;:false,&quot;lqipTransition&quot;:&quot;blur&quot;,&quot;imageData&quot;:{&quot;width&quot;:730,&quot;height&quot;:711,&quot;uri&quot;:&quot;e17082_e2b21efb75a74358a12ec8e6d5288d3e~mv2.png&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;}}" data-bg-effect-name="" data-has-ssr-src="true" data-animate-blur=""><img src="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/e17082_e2b21efb75a74358a12ec8e6d5288d3e~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_73,h_71,al_c,q_85,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01,blur_2,enc_auto/e17082_e2b21efb75a74358a12ec8e6d5288d3e~mv2.png" alt="" style="width:100%;height:100%;object-fit:cover;object-position:50% 50%;max-width:100%" data-pin-url="https://www.securityjoes.com/post/bibi-linux-a-new-wiper-dropped-by-pro-hamas-hacktivist-group" data-pin-media="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/e17082_e2b21efb75a74358a12ec8e6d5288d3e~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_730,h_711,al_c,q_90/e17082_e2b21efb75a74358a12ec8e6d5288d3e~mv2.png"/></wow-image></div><div class="VtuvT" role="button" tabindex="0"><svg viewBox="0 0 19 19" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="leGkP"><path d="M15.071 8.371V4.585l-4.355 4.356a.2.2 0 0 1-.283 0l-.374-.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0-.283l4.356-4.355h-3.786a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2V3.2c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2H16v5.371a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2h-.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2zm-6.5 6.9v.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2H3v-5.371c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2h.529c.11 0 .2.09.2.2v3.786l4.355-4.356a.2.2 0 0 1 .283 0l.374.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0 .283L4.585 15.07h3.786c.11 0 .2.09.2.2z" fill="#000" fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg></div><figcaption dir="auto" class="ki9MR">Figure 2. Hardcoded &quot;BiBi&quot; string within the Wiper sample used for damaged files&#x27; extension</figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div type="image" data-hook="rcv-block26"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-chn1q"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>As mentioned earlier, Wipers are typically associated with politically motivated activists who are not seeking financial gain from their attacks but aim to inflict damage on their adversaries. This case is no exception. Here, we are dealing with an artifact that has no intention of providing victims with any means of file recovery. Instead, its primary objective is to corrupt as many files as swiftly as possible. To achieve this goal, the attackers employed a multi-threaded approach to expedite their operations.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block27"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-597an"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block28"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><h2 class="cqXpV XMpE9 WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-7n4jp"><span class="uZXi0"><span>Dissecting the new </span><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>BiBi-Linux</span></strong><span> Wiper</span></span></h2></div><div type="heading" data-hook="rcv-block29"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-73r8e"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>The malware sample is an x64 ELF executable, coded in C/C++, with a file size of approximately 1.2MB. This binary was compiled using the GCC compiler. Notably, the binary lacks obfuscation, packing, or any protective measures, and it contains several strings that could provide valuable information to analysts right from the beginning of the static analysis (see Figure 3).</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block30"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-finnt"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block31"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-67eji"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>In terms of customization, this binary offers limited options. It only allows the threat actor to specify target folders via command-line parameters. In cases where the attacker does not provide any path, the attack will target the root directory &quot;/&quot;, resulting in the destruction of not only files but also the entire operating system. However, to carry out this destructive action on the OS, the attacker would require root permissions.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block32"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="tqAje" id="viewer-43jc4"><div class="SErax c8QuI" style="width:min(100%, 100%)"><figure role="button" data-hook="imageViewer" tabindex="0" class="Eswhf" aria-haspopup="true"><div style="--dim-height:402;--dim-width:1091" id="43jc4" class="_2ynrX bqdPo z-4Pg"><wow-image id="e17082_5cc889996cbd4c8a8c9f82ffd274abf2~mv2.png" class="undefined O4AJH" data-image-info="{&quot;containerId&quot;:&quot;43jc4&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;,&quot;isLQIP&quot;:true,&quot;isSEOBot&quot;:false,&quot;lqipTransition&quot;:&quot;blur&quot;,&quot;imageData&quot;:{&quot;width&quot;:1091,&quot;height&quot;:402,&quot;uri&quot;:&quot;e17082_5cc889996cbd4c8a8c9f82ffd274abf2~mv2.png&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;}}" data-bg-effect-name="" data-has-ssr-src="true" data-animate-blur=""><img src="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/e17082_5cc889996cbd4c8a8c9f82ffd274abf2~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_49,h_18,al_c,q_85,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01,blur_2,enc_auto/e17082_5cc889996cbd4c8a8c9f82ffd274abf2~mv2.png" alt="" style="width:100%;height:100%;object-fit:cover;object-position:50% 50%;max-width:100%" data-pin-url="https://www.securityjoes.com/post/bibi-linux-a-new-wiper-dropped-by-pro-hamas-hacktivist-group" data-pin-media="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/e17082_5cc889996cbd4c8a8c9f82ffd274abf2~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_1091,h_402,al_c,q_90/e17082_5cc889996cbd4c8a8c9f82ffd274abf2~mv2.png"/></wow-image></div><div class="VtuvT" role="button" tabindex="0"><svg viewBox="0 0 19 19" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="leGkP"><path d="M15.071 8.371V4.585l-4.355 4.356a.2.2 0 0 1-.283 0l-.374-.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0-.283l4.356-4.355h-3.786a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2V3.2c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2H16v5.371a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2h-.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2zm-6.5 6.9v.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2H3v-5.371c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2h.529c.11 0 .2.09.2.2v3.786l4.355-4.356a.2.2 0 0 1 .283 0l.374.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0 .283L4.585 15.07h3.786c.11 0 .2.09.2.2z" fill="#000" fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg></div><figcaption dir="auto" class="ki9MR">Figure 3. Strings and Compiler information found during the static analysis of the malicious artifact.</figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div type="image" data-hook="rcv-block33"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-4pkb4"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>Once executed, the file exhibits a high level of verbosity, continuously printing numerous execution details to the standard output (stdout). These details include information about the targeted path, available processor cores, threads, and the progress of the wiping process. This extensive output to stdout creates a significant amount of noise during execution.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block34"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-fltf7"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block35"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-5soiq"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>To mitigate this issue, threat actors employ the </span><a target="_blank" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nohup" rel="noopener" class="hEuCV uw4qb" data-hook="WebLink"><u style="text-decoration:underline"><span>nohup</span></u></a><span> command when running this tool in targeted environments. By doing so, the program can execute without continuously printing output to the terminal. Instead, the program&#x27;s output is redirected to a file named </span><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>nohup.out</span></strong><span> located in the same directory where the malicious binary was executed. Additionally, using &quot;nohup&quot; prevents the wiping process from halting even if the console is closed.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block36"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="tqAje" id="viewer-v4kt"><div class="SErax c8QuI" style="width:min(100%, 100%)"><figure role="button" data-hook="imageViewer" tabindex="0" class="Eswhf" aria-haspopup="true"><div style="--dim-height:256;--dim-width:1308" id="v4kt" class="_2ynrX bqdPo z-4Pg"><wow-image id="e17082_13f4a8db1f6145af9e6110b83c5138b8~mv2.png" class="undefined O4AJH" data-image-info="{&quot;containerId&quot;:&quot;v4kt&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;,&quot;isLQIP&quot;:true,&quot;isSEOBot&quot;:false,&quot;lqipTransition&quot;:&quot;blur&quot;,&quot;imageData&quot;:{&quot;width&quot;:1308,&quot;height&quot;:256,&quot;uri&quot;:&quot;e17082_13f4a8db1f6145af9e6110b83c5138b8~mv2.png&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;}}" data-bg-effect-name="" data-has-ssr-src="true" data-animate-blur=""><img src="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/e17082_13f4a8db1f6145af9e6110b83c5138b8~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_49,h_10,al_c,q_85,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01,blur_2,enc_auto/e17082_13f4a8db1f6145af9e6110b83c5138b8~mv2.png" alt="" style="width:100%;height:100%;object-fit:cover;object-position:50% 50%;max-width:100%" data-pin-url="https://www.securityjoes.com/post/bibi-linux-a-new-wiper-dropped-by-pro-hamas-hacktivist-group" data-pin-media="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/e17082_13f4a8db1f6145af9e6110b83c5138b8~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_1570,h_307,al_c,lg_1,q_90/e17082_13f4a8db1f6145af9e6110b83c5138b8~mv2.png"/></wow-image></div><div class="VtuvT" role="button" tabindex="0"><svg viewBox="0 0 19 19" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="leGkP"><path d="M15.071 8.371V4.585l-4.355 4.356a.2.2 0 0 1-.283 0l-.374-.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0-.283l4.356-4.355h-3.786a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2V3.2c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2H16v5.371a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2h-.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2zm-6.5 6.9v.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2H3v-5.371c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2h.529c.11 0 .2.09.2.2v3.786l4.355-4.356a.2.2 0 0 1 .283 0l.374.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0 .283L4.585 15.07h3.786c.11 0 .2.09.2.2z" fill="#000" fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg></div><figcaption dir="auto" class="ki9MR">Figure 4. Example of the information printed in the terminal by BiBi Wiper during its execution.</figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div type="image" data-hook="rcv-block37"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-299ea"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><span>To expedite the infection process, this threat leverages multiple threads and employs a queue to synchronize their operations. This approach allows the attack to concurrently corrupt files, significantly enhancing the overall attack&#x27;s reach and speed. Evidence of this can also be found within the sample&#x27;s strings and the syscalls used by the application (see Figure 5). During the code analysis, we identified several Linux syscalls, including </span><em style="font-style:italic"><span>sched_setscheduler</span></em><span>, </span><em style="font-style:italic"><span>sched_getaffinity</span></em><span>, </span><em style="font-style:italic"><span>sched_yield</span></em><span>, </span><em style="font-style:italic"><span>set_robust_list</span></em><span>, </span><em style="font-style:italic"><span>futex </span></em><span>and</span><em style="font-style:italic"><span> set_tid_address</span></em><span>. Collectively, they offer a comprehensive set of tools for controlling the behavior of threads and processes within a Linux application.</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block38"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="tqAje" id="viewer-89f3d"><div class="SErax c8QuI" style="width:min(100%, 100%)"><figure role="button" data-hook="imageViewer" tabindex="0" class="Eswhf" aria-haspopup="true"><div style="--dim-height:451;--dim-width:518" id="89f3d" class="_2ynrX bqdPo z-4Pg"><wow-image id="d03b6f_fe7527419ebf402b85ada172a179185b~mv2.png" class="undefined O4AJH" data-image-info="{&quot;containerId&quot;:&quot;89f3d&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;,&quot;isLQIP&quot;:true,&quot;isSEOBot&quot;:false,&quot;lqipTransition&quot;:&quot;blur&quot;,&quot;imageData&quot;:{&quot;width&quot;:518,&quot;height&quot;:451,&quot;uri&quot;:&quot;d03b6f_fe7527419ebf402b85ada172a179185b~mv2.png&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;displayMode&quot;:&quot;fill&quot;}}" data-bg-effect-name="" data-has-ssr-src="true" data-animate-blur=""><img src="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/d03b6f_fe7527419ebf402b85ada172a179185b~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_52,h_45,al_c,q_85,usm_0.66_1.00_0.01,blur_2,enc_auto/d03b6f_fe7527419ebf402b85ada172a179185b~mv2.png" alt="" style="width:100%;height:100%;object-fit:cover;object-position:50% 50%;max-width:100%" data-pin-url="https://www.securityjoes.com/post/bibi-linux-a-new-wiper-dropped-by-pro-hamas-hacktivist-group" data-pin-media="https://static.wixstatic.com/media/d03b6f_fe7527419ebf402b85ada172a179185b~mv2.png/v1/fill/w_622,h_541,al_c,lg_1,q_85/d03b6f_fe7527419ebf402b85ada172a179185b~mv2.png"/></wow-image></div><div class="VtuvT" role="button" tabindex="0"><svg viewBox="0 0 19 19" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="leGkP"><path d="M15.071 8.371V4.585l-4.355 4.356a.2.2 0 0 1-.283 0l-.374-.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0-.283l4.356-4.355h-3.786a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2V3.2c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2H16v5.371a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2h-.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2-.2zm-6.5 6.9v.529a.2.2 0 0 1-.2.2H3v-5.371c0-.11.09-.2.2-.2h.529c.11 0 .2.09.2.2v3.786l4.355-4.356a.2.2 0 0 1 .283 0l.374.374a.2.2 0 0 1 0 .283L4.585 15.07h3.786c.11 0 .2.09.2.2z" fill="#000" fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg></div><figcaption dir="auto" class="ki9MR">Figure 5. Snippet of code containing syscalls &quot;sched_setscheduler&quot; and &quot;futex&quot;</figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div type="image" data-hook="rcv-block39"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-739v2"><span class="AT4Tn"><span>Once initiated, the attack follows a relatively straightforward logic as a multi-threaded Wiper, characterized by the following actions:</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block40"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><ul class="eON6s WmV-K"><li dir="auto" aria-level="1" class="h4V1a" style="text-align:JUSTIFY;margin-inline-start:1.5em;list-style-type:disc"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="" id="viewer-9rehe"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>File Bricking</span></strong><span>: The malware&#x27;s primary objective is to render files unusable, achieving this by overwriting their contents. Instead of encrypting data, it replaces all the contents of affected files with a buffer of random data of the same length as the targeted file.</span></span></p></li><li dir="auto" aria-level="1" class="h4V1a" style="text-align:JUSTIFY;margin-inline-start:1.5em;list-style-type:disc"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="" id="viewer-ckeo0"><span class="AT4Tn Pohl9"><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>File Renaming</span></strong><span>: In addition to file corruption, the malware renames affected files with a random string, </span><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>appending an extension that includes the substring &quot;BiBi&quot;</span></strong><span> An infected file follows the structure: </span></span></p></li></ul></div><div type="bulleted_list" data-hook="rcv-block41"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><pre class="Rreaj _4EUF1 Pohl9" dir="auto" id="viewer-adbqn"><span class="Pohl9"><span>    [RANDOM_NAME].BiBi[NUMBER]</span></span></pre></div><div type="code_block" data-hook="rcv-block42"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><ul class="eON6s WmV-K"><li dir="auto" aria-level="1" class="h4V1a" style="text-align:AUTO;margin-inline-start:1.5em;list-style-type:disc"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="" id="viewer-1b20n"><span class="AT4Tn"><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>File Type Exclusions</span></strong><span>: Notably, the malware refrains from altering files with the extensions .out or .so. This is because the threat relies on files such as </span><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>bibi-linux.out</span></strong><span> and </span><strong style="font-weight:700"><span>nohup.out</span></strong><span> for its operation, along with shared libraries essential to the Unix/Linux OS (.so files).</span></span></p></li></ul></div><div type="bulleted_list" data-hook="rcv-block43"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="tqAje" id="viewer-3fra4"><div class="SErax" style="width:min(100%, 538px)"><figure role="button" data-hook="imageViewer" tabindex="0" class="Eswhf" aria-haspopup="true"><div style="--dim-height:122;--dim-width:431" id="3fra4" class="_2ynrX bqdPo z-4Pg"><wow-image WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-ebr1n"><span class="AT4Tn"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block45"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><h3 class="ZSacP XMpE9 Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-2124a"><span class="uZXi0 Pohl9"><span>IOCs</span></span></h3></div><div type="heading" data-hook="rcv-block46"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-dhs4s"><span class="AT4Tn"><span>For the time being, we will release only the investigated Wiper sample. </span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block47"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="tqAje" id="viewer-8ti83"><div class="_8Dh7l _7Nm-V"><div class="_6ASqg"><table data-hook="rcv-block48"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><h3 class="ZSacP XMpE9 Pohl9 Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-7j8mm"><span class="uZXi0 Pohl9"><span>Yara Rule</span></span></h3></div><div type="heading" data-hook="rcv-block49"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><pre class="Rreaj _4EUF1 WmV-K" dir="auto" id="viewer-4nl4d"><span class=""><span>
</span><span>​rule BiBi_Linux_Wiper {</span><span>
</span><span>	meta:</span><span>
</span><span>		author =&quot;Felipe Duarte, Security Joes&quot;</span><span>
</span><span>		description =&quot;Detects BiBi-Linux Wiper&quot;</span><span>
</span><span>		sha256_reference =&quot;23bae09b5699c2d5c4cb1b8aa908a3af898b00f88f06e021edcb16d7d558efad&quot;</span><span>
</span><span>		</span><span>
</span><span>    strings:</span><span>
</span><span>		$str1 = &quot;[+] Stats: &quot;</span><span>
</span><span>		$str2 = { 2e 00 00 00 42 00 00 00 69 00 00 00 42 00 00 00 69 00 }</span><span>
</span><span>		$str3 = &quot;[!] Waiting For Queue &quot;</span><span>
</span><span>		$str4 = &quot;[+] Round &quot;</span><span>
</span><span>		$str5 = &quot;[+] Path: &quot;</span><span>
</span><span>		$str6 = &quot;[+] CPU cores: &quot; </span><span>
</span><span>		$str7 = &quot;Threads: &quot;</span><span>
</span><span>
</span><span>	condition:</span><span>
</span><span>		all of them</span><span>
</span><span>}</span></span></pre></div><div type="code_block" data-hook="rcv-block50"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><h2 class="cqXpV XMpE9 mQspv Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-3u5lo"><span class="uZXi0"><span>TTPs</span></span></h2></div><div type="heading" data-hook="rcv-block51"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-63a1q"><span class="AT4Tn"><span>The following is the list of TTPs according to MITRE:</span></span></p></div><div type="paragraph" data-hook="rcv-block52"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="tqAje" id="viewer-4ko1"><div class="_8Dh7l _7Nm-V"><div class="_6ASqg"><table class="caZK0" data-hook="TableComponent"><colgroup><col style="min-width:120px;width:120px"/><col style="min-width:120px;width:120px"/><col style="min-width:120px;width:120px"/></colgroup><tbody><tr style="height:47px"><td data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="background-color:#FF5D5D;vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-kdvv99462"><span class="AT4Tn"><strong style="font-weight:700"><span style="color:#ffffff;text-decoration:inherit"><span>Tactic</span></span></strong></span></p></div></td><td data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" class="WhJ-C" style="background-color:#FF5D5D;vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-4rxu6gr6m"><span class="AT4Tn"><strong data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-nak41bhrs"><span class="AT4Tn"><span>Initial Access</span></span></p></div></td><td data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y mQspv Lbx1y" style="line-height:1.2" Internet-facing host to initially access a network. </span></span></p></div></td></tr><tr style="height:102px"><td data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="vertical-align:top"><div servers.</span></span></p></div></td></tr><tr style="height:47px"><td data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-gqbadmb76"><span class="AT4Tn"><span>Threat scans the system looking for files and folders to infect.</span></span></p></div></td></tr><tr style="height:47px"><td data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="vertical-align:top"><div style="vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y mQspv Lbx1y" style="line-height:1.2" dir="auto" id="viewer-4rm4gucvk"><span class="AT4Tn"><span>System Information Discovery</span></span></p></div></td><td data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-qvag7ep1p"><span class="AT4Tn"><span>Threat get information from the system such as the number of cores and local times.</span></span></p></div></td></tr><tr style="height:47px"><td data-hook="table-plugin-cell" class="WhJ-C" style="vertical-align:top"><div class="_2fK1r oDcWi"><p class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-919lbcmmd"><span data.</span></span></p></div></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></div><div type="table" data-hook="rcv-block53"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-4c3pg"><span class="AT4Tn"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block54"></div><div data-breakout="normal"><div class="qWK-6 Twp3y WmV-K Lbx1y" dir="auto" id="viewer-1b1d4"><span class="AT4Tn"><br role="presentation"/></span></div></div><div type="empty-line" data-hook="rcv-block55"></div></div><div type="last" data-hook="rcv-block-last"></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></article></div><div class="BL3dva"><div class="OSxNQL"><div id="post-footer" class="OFA52E jG7PL8"><div style="text-align:left" <p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text">CROATIA</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text">SPAIN</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text">HUNGARY</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text">COLOMBIA</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text">BRAZIL</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text">ARGENTINA</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text">NEW ZEALAND</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text">AUSTRALIA</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class="font_8 wixui-rich-text__text" style="font-size:15px; line-height:normal;"><span style="color:#B9BBBD;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-size:15px;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="letter-spacing:normal;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span style="font-family:helvetica-w01-light,helvetica-w02-light,sans-serif;" class="wixui-rich-text__text"><span class="wixGuard wixui-rich-text__text">​</span></span></span></span></span></p>

During the forensics investigation, we found what appears to be a new Linux Wiper malware we track as \\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"BiBi-Linux Wiper.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"BOLD\\\",\\\"fontWeightValue\\\":700}]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"AUTO\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"1igle\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"fmnbm\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"This malware is an x64 ELF executable, lacking obfuscation or protective measures. It allows attackers to specify target folders and can potentially destroy an entire operating system if run with root permissions. During execution, it produces extensive output, which can be mitigated using the \\\\\\\"nohup\\\\\\\" command. It also leverages multiple threads and a queue to corrupt files concurrently, enhancing its speed and reach. Its actions include overwriting files, renaming them with a random string containing \\\\\\\"BiBi,\\\\\\\" and excluding certain file types from corruption.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"aarr0\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"e4v3v\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"The article in a nutshell:\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"UNDERLINE\\\",\\\"underlineData\\\":true}]}}],\\\"style\\\":{\\\"paddingTop\\\":\\\"0px\\\",\\\"paddingBottom\\\":\\\"0px\\\"},\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\",\\\"lineHeight\\\":\\\"1.5\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"CODE_BLOCK\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"2ir52\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"1. The attack had no ransom note or C2 servers which increased our confidence that the malware tracked as BiBi-Linux is indeed a Wiper aimed for data destruction \\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"codeBlockData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"}}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"2368q\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"Security for more information about our services and technologies and get additional recommendations to protect yourself against this kind of attack vector.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"HEADING\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"bkt6v\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"headingData\\\":{\\\"level\\\":2,\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"AUTO\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"HEADING\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"64c7q\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"Warzone Cyberweapon\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"headingData\\\":{\\\"level\\\":2,\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"AUTO\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"4ib7l\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"During these times of conflict between Israel & Hamas, our team voluntarily decided to respond to incidents affecting Israeli companies. In the course of our investigations, we encountered a highly specific malware sample that is currently targeting companies across the nation. Unlike the typical global distribution of malware, where financial gain is the common motivation, our analysis of these attacks revealed a different motive. In this case, they are not driven by monetary objectives but are deeply rooted in the political ideologies associated with the ongoing war. This leads us to believe that the specific artifacts discovered may have been created by a group of hackers affiliated with Hamas, with the intent to sow chaos amidst the backdrop of the war.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"1jeru\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"afqd9\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"This new threat does not establish communication with remote Command & Control (C2) servers for data exfiltration, employ reversible encryption algorithms, or leave ransom notes as a means to coerce victims into making payments. Instead, it conducts file corruption by overwriting files with useless data, damaging both the data and the operating system. This category of destructive software is commonly referred to as a \\\\\\\"Wiper\\\\\\\" and is not a recent phenomenon.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"2efn0\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"faut0\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"Reports of this type of malware have been documented targeting devices in previous years, affecting both \\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"Windows\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"LINK\\\",\\\"linkData\\\":{\\\"link\\\":{\\\"url\\\":\\\"https:\/\/www.vectra.ai\/blog\/an-analysis-of-the-shamoon-2-malware-attack\\\",\\\"target\\\":\\\"BLANK\\\"}}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"UNDERLINE\\\",\\\"underlineData\\\":true}]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\" and \\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"Linux\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"LINK\\\",\\\"linkData\\\":{\\\"link\\\":{\\\"url\\\":\\\"https:\/\/www.sentinelone.com\/labs\/acidrain-a-modem-wiper-rains-down-on-europe\/\\\",\\\"target\\\":\\\"BLANK\\\"}}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"UNDERLINE\\\",\\\"underlineData\\\":true}]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\" systems. Instead, its primary objective is to corrupt as many files as swiftly as possible. To achieve this goal, the attackers employed a multi-threaded approach to expedite their operations.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"597an\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"HEADING\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"7n4jp\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"Dissecting the new \\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"BiBi-Linux\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"BOLD\\\",\\\"fontWeightValue\\\":700}]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\" Wiper\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"headingData\\\":{\\\"level\\\":2,\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"AUTO\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"73r8e\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"The malware sample is an x64 ELF executable, coded in C\/C++, with a file size of approximately 1.2MB. This binary was compiled using the GCC compiler. Notably, the binary lacks obfuscation, packing, or any protective measures, and it contains several strings that could provide valuable information to analysts right from the beginning of the static analysis (see Figure 3).\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"finnt\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"67eji\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"In terms of customization, this binary offers limited options. It only allows the threat actor to specify target folders via command-line parameters. In cases where the attacker does not provide any path, the attack will target the root directory \\\\\\\"\/\\\\\\\", resulting in the destruction of not only files but also the entire operating system. However, to carry out this destructive action on the OS, the attacker would require root permissions.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"IMAGE\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"43jc4\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"imageData\\\":{\\\"containerData\\\":{\\\"width\\\":{\\\"size\\\":\\\"CONTENT\\\"},\\\"alignment\\\":\\\"CENTER\\\",\\\"spoiler\\\":{\\\"enabled\\\":false},\\\"textWrap\\\":true},\\\"image\\\":{\\\"src\\\":{\\\"id\\\":\\\"e17082_5cc889996cbd4c8a8c9f82ffd274abf2~mv2.png\\\"},\\\"width\\\":1091,\\\"height\\\":402},\\\"disableExpand\\\":false,\\\"caption\\\":\\\"Figure 3. Strings and Compiler information found during the static analysis of the malicious artifact.\\\",\\\"disableDownload\\\":false}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"4pkb4\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"Once executed, the file exhibits a high level of verbosity, continuously printing numerous execution details to the standard output (stdout). These details include information about the targeted path, available processor cores, threads, and the progress of the wiping process. This extensive output to stdout creates a significant amount of noise during execution.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"fltf7\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"PARAGRAPH\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"5soiq\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"To mitigate this issue, threat actors employ the \\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\"nohup\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[{\\\"type\\\":\\\"LINK\\\",\\\"linkData\\\":{\\\"link\\\":{\\\"url\\\":\\\"https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Nohup\\\",\\\"target\\\":\\\"BLANK\\\"}}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"UNDERLINE\\\",\\\"underlineData\\\":true}]}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"TEXT\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"textData\\\":{\\\"text\\\":\\\" command when running this tool in targeted environments. Additionally, using \\\\\\\"nohup\\\\\\\" prevents the wiping process from halting even if the console is closed.\\\",\\\"decorations\\\":[]}}],\\\"paragraphData\\\":{\\\"textStyle\\\":{\\\"textAlignment\\\":\\\"JUSTIFY\\\"},\\\"indentation\\\":0}},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"IMAGE\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"v4kt\\\",\\\"nodes\\\":[],\\\"imageData\\\":{\\\"containerData\\\":{\\\"width\\\":{\\\"size\\\":\\\"CONTENT\\\"},\\\"alignment\\\":\\\"CENTER\\\",\\\"spoiler\\\":{\\\"enabled\\\":false},\\\"textWrap\\\":true},\\\"image\\\":{\\\"src\\\":{\\\"id\\\":\\\"e17082_13f4a8db1f6145af9e6110b83c5138b8~mv2.png\\\"},\\\"width\\\":1308,\\\"height\\\":256},\\\"disableExpand\\\":false,\\\"caption\\\":\\\"Figure 4.
